Description: This is the last alpha version developed primarily by Ihaka and Gentleman. Much of the basic functionality from the "White Book" (see S history) was implemented. The mailing lists commenced on April 1, 1997.

This is the oldest source release which is currently available on CRAN.[47] CRAN is started on this date, with 3 mirrors that initially hosted 12 packages.[48] Alpha versions of R for Microsoft Windows and the classic Mac OS are made available shortly after this version.[citation needed]
R becomes an official part of the GNU Project. The code is hosted and maintained on CVS.
First versions of update.packages and install.packages functions for downloading and installing packages from CRAN.[49]
Considered by its developers stable enough for production use.[50]
S4 methods are introduced and the first version for Mac OS X is made available soon after.
Introduced a flexible condition handling mechanism for signalling and handling condition objects.
Introduced lazy loading, which enables fast loading of data with minimal expense of system memory.
Support for UTF-8 encoding, and the beginnings of internationalization and localization for different languages.
Adding a new compiler function that allows speeding up functions by converting them to byte-code.
Added mandatory namespaces for packages. Added a new parallel package.
New load balancing functions. Improved serialisation speed for long vectors.
Support for numeric index values 231 and larger on 64 bit systems.
Just-in-time compilation (JIT) of functions and loops to byte-code enabled by default.
Packages byte-compiled on installation by default. Compact internal representation of integer sequences. Added a new serialisation format to support compact internal representations.

R CMD config knows the value of AR and RANLIB, often set for LTO (link-time optimization) builds. Deprecated: The use of a character vector with .Fortran() is formally deprecated and gives a non-portability warning. (It has long been strongly discouraged in Writing R Extensions.[26])
